author: Grimms
text: A certain cat had made the acquaintance of a mouse, and had said so much to her about the great love and friendship she felt for her, that at length the mouse agreed that they should live and keep house together.

author: Grimms
text: "But we must make a provision for winter, or else we shall suffer from hunger," said the cat; "and you, little mouse, cannot venture everywhere, or you will be caught in a trap some day."

author: Grimms
text: The good advice was followed, and a pot of fat was bought, but they did not know where to put it.

author: Grimms
text: At length, after much consideration, the cat said: "I know no place where it will be better stored up than in the church, for no one dares take anything away from there.

author: Grimms
text: We will set it beneath the altar, and not touch it until we are really in need of it."

author: Grimms
text: So the pot was placed in safety, but it was not long before the cat had a great yearning for it, and said to the mouse: "I want to tell you something, little mouse; my cousin has brought a little son into the world, and has asked me to be godmother; he is white with brown spots, and I am to hold him over the font at the christening.

author: Grimms
text: Let me go out today, and you look after the house by yourself."

author: Grimms
text: "Yes, yes," answered the mouse, "by all means go, and if you get anything very good to eat, think of me.

author: Grimms
text: I should like a drop of sweet red christening wine myself."

author: Grimms
text: All this, however, was untrue; the cat had no cousin, and had not been asked to be godmother.

author: Grimms
text: She went straight to the church, stole to the pot of fat, began to lick at it, and licked the top of the fat off.

author: Grimms
text: Then she took a walk upon the roofs of the town, looked out for opportunities, and then stretched herself in the sun, and licked her lips whenever she thought of the pot of fat, and not until it was evening did she return home.

author: Grimms
text: "Well, here you are again," said the mouse, "no doubt you have had a merry day."

author: Grimms
text: "All went off well," answered the cat.

author: Grimms
text: "What name did they give the child?"

author: Grimms
text: "Top off!" said the cat quite coolly.

author: Grimms
text: "Top off!" cried the mouse, "that is a very odd and uncommon name, is it a usual one in your family?"

author: Grimms
text: "What does that matter," said the cat, "it is no worse than Crumb-stealer, as your godchildren are called."

author: Grimms
text: Before long the cat was seized by another fit of yearning.

author: Grimms
text: She said to the mouse: "You must do me a favour, and once more manage the house for a day alone.

author: Grimms
text: I am again asked to be godmother, and, as the child has a white ring round its neck, I cannot refuse."

author: Grimms
text: The good mouse consented, but the cat crept behind the town walls to the church, and devoured half the pot of fat.

author: Grimms
text: "Nothing ever seems so good as what one keeps to oneself," said she, and was quite satisfied with her day"s work.

author: Grimms
text: When she went home the mouse inquired: "And what was the child christened?"

author: Grimms
text: "Half-done," answered the cat.

author: Grimms
text: "Half-done!

author: Grimms
text: What are you saying?

author: Grimms
text: I never heard the name in my life, I"ll wager anything it is not in the calendar!"

author: Grimms
text: The cat"s mouth soon began to water for some more licking.

author: Grimms
text: "All good things go in threes," said she, "I am asked to stand godmother again.

author: Grimms
text: The child is quite black, only it has white paws, but with that exception, it has not a single white hair on its whole body; this only happens once every few years, you will let me go, won"t you?"

author: Grimms
text: "Topoff!

author: Grimms
text: Half-done!" answered the mouse, "they are such odd names, they make me very thoughtful."

author: Grimms
text: "You sit at home," said the cat, "in your dark-grey fur coat and long tail, and are filled with fancies, that"s because you do not go out in the daytime."

author: Grimms
text: During the cat"s absence the mouse cleaned the house, and put it in order, but the greedy cat entirely emptied the pot of fat.

author: Grimms
text: "When everything is eaten up one has some peace," said she to herself, and well filled and fat she did not return home till night.

author: Grimms
text: The mouse at once asked what name had been given to the third child.

author: Grimms
text: "It will not please you more than the others," said the cat.

author: Grimms
text: "He is called All-gone."

author: Grimms
text: "All-gone," cried the mouse "that is the most suspicious name of all!

author: Grimms
text: I have never seen it in print.

author: Grimms
text: All-gone; what can that mean?" and she shook her head, curled herself up, and lay down to sleep.

author: Grimms
text: From this time forth no one invited the cat to be godmother, but when the winter had come and there was no longer anything to be found outside, the mouse thought of their provision, and said: "Come, cat, we will go to our pot of fat which we have stored up for ourselves--we shall enjoy that."

author: Grimms
text: "Yes," answered the cat, "you will enjoy it as much as you would enjoy sticking that dainty tongue of yours out of the window."

author: Grimms
text: They set out on their way, but when they arrived, the pot of fat certainly was still in its place, but it was empty.

author: Grimms
text: "Alas!" said the mouse, "now I see what has happened, now it comes to light!

author: Grimms
text: You a true friend!

author: Grimms
text: You have devoured all when you were standing godmother.

author: Grimms
text: First top off, then half-done, then--" "Will you hold your tongue," cried the cat, "one word more, and I will eat you too."

author: Grimms
text: "All-gone" was already on the poor mouse"s lips; scarcely had she spoken it before the cat sprang on her, seized her, and swallowed her down.

author: Grimms
text: Verily, that is the way of the world.
